page.title: 16HOUSING IN TRETHURGY
page.content: In the mid nineteenth century, Trethurgy was a thriving tin mining village with Ruby Cottage, built in 1835, the headquarters. Most land belonged to the Trevannions of the Treverbyn Estate. In response to the mining boom, a major building programme started in 1862 with the construction of a Chapel and school. Later in the century, tin mining collapsed and the population gradually declined. In 1930, with falling rolls, the school closed. Recently, with the growth of the China Clay industry, the population is growing and new houses are being built. Nevertheless, the Chapel closed in 1985, due to low attendances. Both the Chapel and school remain in the village, but neither carry out their original function.
